tags: this is so bad but oh well
summary: hi! i love your blog and I was wondering if you’d be so kind to write a small fic about gendrya right before the battle of...
question: hi! i love your blog and I was wondering if you’d be so kind to write a small fic about gendrya right before the battle of Winterfell?
answer:
hi ily it’s not very good and it’s all i could do atm because I’m not very good at writing but u asked so I will deliver x

————————————————————————-

Walking out of the crypts and away from Sansa and Bran was one of the hardest things she’s ever had to do. But she knew that if she and Winterfell were to fall tonight, Sansa and Bran would have a chance of surviving down there in the crypts. Protected by the Starks of the North, Kings and Queens of Winter itself. She took solace in knowing that Sansa was efficient enough to get both and her Bran out of Winterfell when the situation becomes dire.


Walking up toward the front line of the army felt strange to her. She’d never been here, she knew the day was coming. She just thought she would be facing Lannister men and not the dead who aren’t technically dead. Jon stood to her left and Gendry to her right. Her old friend looked fierce in his northern furs and leather, a warhammer with dragon glass tipped spikes firm in his hand. He looked strong and intimidating and damningly handsome. Arya quickly looked away and took the time to make sure her Valyrian Steel dagger was at her hip. It was safely strapped to her, waiting for a kill. Her bow, tipped with dragon glass on both ends, rested soundly in her left land…waiting. It felt like a life time before she could see the distant glow of blue eyes in the distant. Suddenly everyone readied, drawing their swords, daggers and spears.

“Arya.” She heard, turning her head toward Gendry she looked at him in question. Panic was all over his face. Hers too, she had no doubt.

“Yes?” She asked, checking him over to see if he was ok. After all he’d never really been in a real battle either. No matter what Hot Pie said, armour doesn’t equal battle.

“Nothing. I just wanted to see your face one last time.” Gendry hoarsely whispered, she hardly heard him. Her eyes glazed over with fresh tears but she would not cry. Because this would not be the last time they look into each other’s eyes.

“This won’t be the last time.” She states it forcefully and tenderly at the same time, his face softened and he smirked.

“Still. I want to see something pleasant before this happens.” He said, they stood staring tenderly into each other’s eyes. Arya wanted to embrace him and Gendry looked about ready to do the same thing.

“If you two are done flirting, the North still needs saving.” The Hound had said, moving to stand protectively behind the two. Arya looked away from Gendry sheepishly. He had a slight blush on his cheeks while looking into the distance at the wights. She bit her lip before looking back to him.

“Gendry?” She asked, quickly, glancing between him and the approaching army.

“Yes?” He asked, turning to look at her. His heated stare never faltering.

“We live through this you can stare at my face any time of the day, near death situations or not. Whenever you like.” Only Arya would admit to having feelings without actually admitting she has feelings. Gendry smiled brightly, his Baratheon blue eyes glowing almost as much as a wights.

“Now I’m definitely not dying now, m’lady.” He said, trying to keep the quiver out of his voice. Arya rolled her eyes.

“Don’t call me m’lady.” Gendry sighed exasperated.

“You’re really going to berate me for it right before our deaths?” He asked, slightly amused yet slightly annoyed.

“Yes, stupid.” She started to yell as the winds got louder, she heard Gendry chuckle between the howling of the wind. This was it. The Great War was here.

blog.name: bookaryastark
blog.title: Daughter of the North
blog.description: That night she dreamed she was a wolf again, but it was different from the other dreams. In this dream she had no pack. She prowled alone, bounding over rooftops and padding silently beside the banks of a canal, stalking shadows through the fog.

summary: Fear cuts deeper than swords, the quiet voice inside her whispered. Suddenly Arya remembered the crypts at Winterfell. They were...
body:
Fear cuts deeper than swords, the quiet voice inside her whispered. Suddenly Arya remembered the crypts at Winterfell. They were a lot scarier than this place, she told herself. She’d been just a little girl the first time she saw them. Her brother Robb had taken them down, her and Sansa and baby Bran, who’d been no bigger than Rickon was now. They’d only had one candle between them, and Bran’s eyes had gotten as big as saucers as he stared at the stone faces of the Kings of Winter, with their wolves at their feet and their iron swords across their laps.
Robb took them all the way down to the end, past Grandfather and Brandon and Lyanna, to show them their own tombs. Sansa kept looking at the stubby little candle, anxious that it might go out. Old Nan had told her there were spiders down here, and rats as big as dogs. Robb smiled when she said that. “There are worse things than spiders and rats,” he whispered. “This is where the dead walk.” That was when they heard the sound, low and deep and shivery. Baby Bran had clutched at Arya’s hand.
When the spirit stepped out of the open tomb, pale white and moaning for blood, Sansa ran shrieking for the stairs, and Bran wrapped himself around Robb’s leg, sobbing. Arya stood her ground and gave the spirit a punch. It was only Jon, covered with flour. “You stupid,” she told him, “you scared the baby,” but Jon and Robb just laughed and laughed, and pretty soon Bran and Arya were laughing too.
The memory made Arya smile, and after that the darkness held no more terrors for her. The stableboy was dead, she’d killed him, and if he jumped out at her she’d kill him again. She was going home. Everything would be better once she was home again, safe behind Winterfell’s grey granite walls.
Her footsteps sent soft echoes hurrying ahead of her as Arya plunged deeper into the darkness.

(George R.R. Martin, A Game of Thrones)

Robb took them all the way down to the end, past Grandfather and Brandon and Lyanna, to show them their own tombs. Sansa kept looking at the stubby little candle, anxious that it might go out. Old Nan had told her there were spiders down here, and rats as big as dogs. Robb smiled when she said that. “There are worse things than spiders and rats,” he whispered. “This is where the dead walk.” That was when they heard the sound, low and deep and shivery. Baby Bran had clutched at Arya’s hand.
When the spirit stepped out of the open tomb, pale white and moaning for blood, Sansa ran shrieking for the stairs, and Bran wrapped himself around Robb’s leg, sobbing. Arya stood her ground and gave the spirit a punch. It was only Jon, covered with flour. “You stupid,” she told him, “you scared the baby,” but Jon and Robb just laughed and laughed, and pretty soon Bran and Arya were laughing too.
The memory made Arya smile, and after that the darkness held no more terrors for her. The stableboy was dead, she’d killed him, and if he jumped out at her she’d kill him again. She was going home. Everything would be better once she was home again, safe behind Winterfell’s grey granite walls.
Her footsteps sent soft echoes hurrying ahead of her as Arya plunged deeper into the darkness.

(George R.R. Martin, A Game of Thrones)

trail.content_raw:
Fear cuts deeper than swords, the quiet voice inside her whispered. Suddenly Arya remembered the crypts at Winterfell. They were a lot scarier than this place, she told herself. She’d been just a little girl the first time she saw them. Her brother Robb had taken them down, her and Sansa and baby Bran, who’d been no bigger than Rickon was now. They’d only had one candle between them, and Bran’s eyes had gotten as big as saucers as he stared at the stone faces of the Kings of Winter, with their wolves at their feet and their iron swords across their laps.
Robb took them all the way down to the end, past Grandfather and Brandon and Lyanna, to show them their own tombs. Sansa kept looking at the stubby little candle, anxious that it might go out. Old Nan had told her there were spiders down here, and rats as big as dogs. Robb smiled when she said that. “There are worse things than spiders and rats,” he whispered. “This is where the dead walk.” That was when they heard the sound, low and deep and shivery. Baby Bran had clutched at Arya’s hand.
When the spirit stepped out of the open tomb, pale white and moaning for blood, Sansa ran shrieking for the stairs, and Bran wrapped himself around Robb’s leg, sobbing. Arya stood her ground and gave the spirit a punch. It was only Jon, covered with flour. “You stupid,” she told him, “you scared the baby,” but Jon and Robb just laughed and laughed, and pretty soon Bran and Arya were laughing too.
The memory made Arya smile, and after that the darkness held no more terrors for her. The stableboy was dead, she’d killed him, and if he jumped out at her she’d kill him again. She was going home. Everything would be better once she was home again, safe behind Winterfell’s grey granite walls.
Her footsteps sent soft echoes hurrying ahead of her as Arya plunged deeper into the darkness.

(George R.R. Martin, A Game of Thrones)
trail.content:
Fear cuts deeper than swords, the quiet voice inside her whispered. Suddenly Arya remembered the crypts at Winterfell. They were a lot scarier than this place, she told herself. She’d been just a little girl the first time she saw them. Her brother Robb had taken them down, her and Sansa and baby Bran, who’d been no bigger than Rickon was now. They’d only had one candle between them, and Bran’s eyes had gotten as big as saucers as he stared at the stone faces of the Kings of Winter, with their wolves at their feet and their iron swords across their laps.
Robb took them all the way down to the end, past Grandfather and Brandon and Lyanna, to show them their own tombs. Sansa kept looking at the stubby little candle, anxious that it might go out. Old Nan had told her there were spiders down here, and rats as big as dogs. Robb smiled when she said that. “There are worse things than spiders and rats,” he whispered. “This is where the dead walk.” That was when they heard the sound, low and deep and shivery. Baby Bran had clutched at Arya’s hand.
When the spirit stepped out of the open tomb, pale white and moaning for blood, Sansa ran shrieking for the stairs, and Bran wrapped himself around Robb’s leg, sobbing. Arya stood her ground and gave the spirit a punch. It was only Jon, covered with flour. “You stupid,” she told him, “you scared the baby,” but Jon and Robb just laughed and laughed, and pretty soon Bran and Arya were laughing too.
The memory made Arya smile, and after that the darkness held no more terrors for her. The stableboy was dead, she’d killed him, and if he jumped out at her she’d kill him again. She was going home. Everything would be better once she was home again, safe behind Winterfell’s grey granite walls.
Her footsteps sent soft echoes hurrying ahead of her as Arya plunged deeper into the darkness.

(George R.R. Martin, A Game of Thrones)

blog.description: Jenny - 31 - Taking over Westeros one pie at a time! - this blog has become a bit of a grab bag: Game of Thrones, Cosmere, Six of Crows, Roswell NM, the 100, custom pop toys, random art and whatever else I’m into at the moment. (Emmerdale sideblog is Scrapyardboyfriends)
